(Such as asking the Recommender to recommend another item.)\n3. No, the Seeker has rejected the Recommender\'s recommendation. (The Seeker has explicitly rejected the recommendation.)\n4. Yes, the Seeker is interested in the recommendation. (Such as asking the Recommender to tell more about the recommended item. )\n5. Yes, the Seeker has accepted the Recommender\'s recommendation. (Such as asking the Recommender to recommend another item.)\n3. No, the Seeker has rejected the Recommender\'s recommendation. (The Seeker has explicitly rejected the recommendation.)\n4. No, the Recommender has not yet made a recommendation to the Seeker. (The Recommender has not mentioned any specific item.)\n2. No, the Seeker is not interested in the recommendation. (Such as asking the Recommender to recommend another item.)\n3. No, the Seeker has rejected the Recommender\'s recommendation. (The Seeker has explicitly rejected the recommendation.)\n4. Yes, the Seeker is interested in the recommendation. (Such as asking the Recommender to tell more about the recommended item. )\n5. Yes, the Seeker has accepted the Recommender\'s recommendation. (Only if the Seeker has explicitly indicated acceptance, such as stating they will try watching it, you can consider the recommendation as accepted.)\n\nPlease make sure your response is only one of the five options, and output corresponding sentence without contents in the brackets and without any other words.\n\nThe conversation history is as follows: \nSeeker: Hello.\nRecommender: Hi! I\'m here to help you find a great movie. What kind of movies are you in the mood for?\nSeeker: Hi! Nice to meet you. I\'m not sure, to be honest. I\'ve been watching a lot of documentaries lately, but I\'m open to something new. What do you recommend?\nRecommender: You\'ve been enjoying documentaries, have you? That\'s a great starting point! However, I need a bit more information about your preferences. Can you tell me what specifically draws you to documentaries? Is it the historical aspect, the storytelling, or something else?\nSeeker: Well, I think it\'s a mix of everything. I love learning new things, and documentaries often provide a unique perspective on current events or historical events. But I also appreciate a good story, and documentaries can be quite engaging when they\'re well-made. What do you think? Do you have any recommendations?\nRecommender: I think that\'s a great approach to documentaries! With your interest in learning and storytelling, I\'d like to recommend "For the Love of Movies" (2009). It\'s a documentary that explores the history of American film criticism, which might interest you given your appreciation for learning and unique perspectives.\nSeeker: "For the Love of Movies" sounds interesting, but I\'m not sure if I\'d enjoy it. Can you tell me more about the documentary? What\'s it about, and what kind of tone does it have?\nRecommender: "For the Love of Movies" is a documentary that delves into the world of film criticism, featuring interviews with renowned critics like Roger Ebert and Andrew Sarris. The documentary provides a historical context, exploring the evolution of film criticism over the years.\nSeeker: That sounds fascinating, but I\'m still a bit hesitant. I\'m not sure if I\'d be interested in a documentary about film criticism. Can you recommend something else that might be more to my taste?\nRecommender: I\'d like to ask, what specifically about the documentary on film criticism didn\'t appeal to you? Was it the subject matter, the tone, or something else?\nSeeker: I think it\'s just that I\'m not sure if I\'d be interested in a documentary about film criticism. I\'m more interested in documentaries that explore social issues or historical events. Do you have any recommendations in those areas?\nRecommender: I\'d like to recommend "Cinemania" (2002). It\'s a documentary that explores the culture of intense cinephilia in New York City, revealing the world of five obsessed movie buffs. The documentary exposes this delightfully deranged cult and provides a unique perspective on the world of film enthusiasts.\nSeeker: "Cinemania" sounds intriguing, but I\'m still not sure. Can you tell me more about the documentary? What\'s it about, and what kind of tone does it have?\nRecommender: "Cinemania" is a documentary that delves into the world of film enthusiasts, showcasing their passion and dedication to cinema. The documentary provides a fascinating look into the lives of these individuals, offering a unique perspective on the world of film.\nSeeker: I\'m still not sure about "Cinemania". I think I\'d like to see something that\'s a bit more mainstream, something that\'s going to appeal to a wider audience. Do you have any recommendations in that area?\nRecommender: I\'d like to recommend "What Is Cinema?" (2013). It\'s a documentary that explores the question of what cinema is, featuring interviews with renowned filmmakers and critics.
